com.rli.util.djava

Class VDSFunction

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.rli.util.djava.VDSFunction

  • public abstract class VDSFunction
extends java.lang.Object
    VDSFunction: supports script functions. 
      Some of the functions:
  rdn(param) //rdn a=1
  rdnval(param) //rdnval 1
  parent(param) //dn parent
  left(param,nbchar) //left substring
  leftsubstring(param,'string') //left substring + trim()
  right(param,nbchar)//right substring
  rightsubstring(param,'string') //right substring + trim()
  upper(param) //to upper case
  lower(param) //to lower case

  Example:
  parent(refdn)
  left(middlename,1)
  left(name,"@")

      • right

        public static java.lang.String right(java.lang.String value,
                                     java.lang.String separ)
        Rightmost characters of the replace string are returned after the separator string. If separator is not found in the the replace string, the replace string is returned.

        Example: 

         right("name@domain.com","@") returns "domain.com";
 right("name@domain.com","#") returns "name@domain.com";
        Parameters:
        value - the replace string
        separ - separator
        Returns:
        The resulting String.

        public java.lang.String lookup(java.lang.String dataSourceID,
                               java.lang.String baseDn,
                               int scope,
                               java.lang.String filter,

                        throws javax.naming.NamingException,
                               java.io.IOException,
                               LDAPException
        execute a LDAP lookup and store value(s) in attribute returned.
        Parameters:
        dataSourceID - Data Source Name as defined in "Data Sources" configuration
        baseDn - Base DN to use, could be an attribute or a static DN value
        scope - 0:base, 1:one or 2:sub
        filter - filter to apply on external source, could be a combination of attributes and static string values
        attrName - attrName to return from external entries, if not specified (null), then will store DN in result
        sizeLimit - number of external entries returned
        Returns:
        The resulting String.
        Throws:
        LDAPException
        java.io.IOException
        javax.naming.NamingException

      • remapDN

        public static java.lang.String remapDN(java.lang.String dn,
                                       java.lang.String dnTemplate)
        Re-map original DN attribute using a DN template. DN template is a representation of re-mapped pattern, it can use with place holders %rdn and %dn. %rdn is the rdn value of the original DN. %dn is the value of original DN.

        Example: remapDN(memberOf,"uid=%rdn,dc=my_users"). %rdn will be replaced with the rdn value extracted from the memberof attribute.

        Example: remapDN(memberOf,"%dn,dc=my_users") will add a suffix to the original dn

        Parameters:
        dn - DN type attribute. Example: cn=test,ou=mycompany,dc=com
        dnTemplate - DN Template representation of re-mapped value. Example: uid=%rdn,dv=ad_10_11_12_203_389_users
        Returns:
        The resulting String

      • replace

        public static java.lang.String replace(java.lang.String replace,
                                       java.lang.String pattern,
                                       java.lang.String replacement)
        Replaces the first substring of the replace string that matches the given regular expression pattern with the given replacement. If the regular expression pattern is not correct, the replace string is returned unchanged.

        Example: replace("abCDab","ab","AB") returns "ABCDab"

        Parameters:
        replace - the replace string
        pattern - the regular expression to which the replace string is to be matched
        replacement - the string to be substituted for the first match
        Returns:
        The resulting String. If the regular expression pattern is not correct, the attribute is returned unchanged.

      • replaceAll

        public static java.lang.String replaceAll(java.lang.String replace,
                                          java.lang.String pattern,
                                          java.lang.String replacement)
        Replaces each substring of the replace string that matches the given regular expression pattern with the given replacement. If the regular expression pattern is not correct, the replace string is returned unchanged.

        Example: replace("abCDab","ab","AB") returns "ABCDAB"

        Parameters:
        replace - the replace string
        pattern - the regular expression to which the replace string is to be matched
        replacement - the string to be substituted for each match
        Returns:
        The resulting String. If the regular expression pattern is not correct, the attribute is returned unchanged.

      • replaceX

        public static java.lang.String replaceX(java.lang.String toreplace,
                                        java.lang.String rules)
        Replaces each substring of the attribute values that matches the given regular expression pattern with the given replacement. If the regular expression pattern is not correct, the original value is returned unchanged.

        Example: replaceX("San Francisco",{"San"} --> {"SAN"}) returns "SAN Francisco"

        Parameters:
        toreplace - the string to be replaced
        rules - rules: regular expressions to which the string to replace is to be matched with . regular expression1-->replacement1 ##regular expression2-->replacement2" the replacement pattern can be an ldap url , that is evaluated for lookup "(.+) --> ldap://[vds]/o=companydirectory?dn?sub?(l=$1)" simplified form : o=companydirectory?dn?sub?(l=$1)
        Returns:
        The resulting String. If the regular expression pattern is not correct,or no regex matches, the attribute is returned unchanged.

      • replaceXnull

        public static java.lang.String replaceXnull(java.lang.String toreplace,
                                            java.lang.String rules)
        Replaces each substring of the attribute values that matches the given regular expression pattern with the given replacement. If the regular expression pattern is not correct, a 'null' value is returned

        Example: replaceXnull("Francisco",{"San"} --> {"SAN"}) returns null

        Parameters:
        toreplace - the string to be replaced
        rules - rules: regular expressions to which the string to replace is to be matched with . regular expression1-->replacement1 ##regular expression2-->replacement2" the replacement pattern can be an ldap url , that is evaluated for lookup "(.+) --> ldap://[vds]/o=companydirectory?dn?sub?(l=$1)" simplified form : o=companydirectory?dn?sub?(l=$1)
        Returns:
        The resulting String. If the regular expression pattern is not correct,or no regex matches, the value returned is null.

      • normalizeString

        public static java.lang.String normalizeString(java.lang.String attribute)
        1. Removes leading and trailing white space from the attribute and changes multiple spaces in the middle of the attribute to a single space. 2. Converts all characters to upper case 3. Replaces special characters by '_', and then replaces multiple consecutive '_' into one '_'. Special characters are: !\"#$%&'()*+,-./:;<=>?[\\]^`{|}~" 4. If attribute is null, returns empty string.
        Parameters:
        attribute - the replaced string
        Returns:
        normalized string

      • replaceChars

        public static java.lang.String replaceChars(java.lang.String str,
                                            java.lang.String searchChars,
                                            java.lang.String replaceChars)
        This method is wrapper of org.apache.commons.lang.StringUtils.replaceChars with one change: A null string input returns an empty ("") string.

        Replaces multiple characters in a String in one go. This method can also be used to delete characters.

        For example: replaceChars("hello", "ho", "jy") = jelly.

        A null string input returns an empty ("") string. An empty ("") string input returns an empty string. A null or empty set of search characters returns the input string.

        The length of the search characters should normally equal the length of the replace characters. If the search characters is longer, then the extra search characters are deleted. If the search characters is shorter, then the extra replace characters are ignored.

        Parameters:
        str - - String to replace characters in, may be null
        searchChars - - a set of characters to search for, may be null
        replaceChars - - a set of characters to replace, may be null
        Returns:
        modified String

      • randomAscii

        public static java.lang.String randomAscii(int count)
        Creates a random string whose length is the number of characters specified. Characters will be chosen from the set of characters whose ASCII value is between 32 and 126 (inclusive).

        This is a wrapper of org.apache.commons.lang.RandomStringUtils.randomAscii(count) method with one change: if count<=0, a random string of length 1 is returned. ( Apache method throws an exception if count<0, or returns empty string if count=0. )

        Example: randomAscii(10) returns random string of length 10.

        Parameters:
        count - the length of random string to create
        Returns:
        the random string

      • normalizeFirstName

        public static java.lang.String normalizeFirstName(java.lang.String attribute)
        Normalizes the non-standard first name attribute into standard first name using normalization file firstname.dat which located in RLI_HOME/vds/ontology/normalization directory. All data in this file is in UPPERCASE, so in order to be matched the input attribute must be in UPPERCASE. If no match is found, the input attribute is returned.

        Example: normalizeFirstName("BOB") ) returns "ROBERT"

        Parameters:
        attribute - first name attribute
        Returns:
        The resulting String. If no match is found, the input attribute is returned.

      • normalizeAttribute

        public static java.lang.String normalizeAttribute(java.lang.String attribute,
                                                  java.lang.String normalizedFileName)
        Normalizes the non-standard attribute into standard attribute using normalization file normalizedFileName which must be located in RLI_HOME/vds/ontology/normalization directory. The format of this file is: 
         NON_NORMALIZED_VALUE_1|NORMALIZED_VALUE_1
 NON_NORMALIZED_VALUE_2|NORMALIZED_VALUE_2
 NON_NORMALIZED_VALUE_3|NORMALIZED_VALUE_3
 ....

        I.e. each pair (non-normilized value and normalized value) should be on a separate line, non-normalized value goes first, then separator - |, then normilized value.

        Example (from firstname.dat): 

         ALAINA|ALANA
 ALAINE|ALANA
 ALANE|ALANA

        If no match is found, the input attribute is returned.

        Example: normalizeAttribute("BOB","firstname.dat") ) returns "ROBERT"

        Parameters:
        attribute - attribute that should be normalized
        normalizedFileName - the name of the file where normalization data is described.
        Returns:
        The resulting String. If no match is found, the input attribute is returned.

      • replaceFromDictionary

        public static java.lang.String replaceFromDictionary(java.lang.String attribute,
                                                     java.lang.String dictionaryFileName,
                                                     java.lang.String defaultValue)
        Normalizes the non-standard attribute into standard attribute using normalization file normalizedFileName which must be located in RLI_HOME/vds/ontology/normalization directory. The format of this file is: 
         NON_NORMALIZED_VALUE_1|NORMALIZED_VALUE_1
 NON_NORMALIZED_VALUE_2|NORMALIZED_VALUE_2
 NON_NORMALIZED_VALUE_3|NORMALIZED_VALUE_3
 ....

        I.e. each pair (non-normalized value and normalized value) should be on a separate line, non-normalized value goes first, then separator - |, then normalized value.

        Example (from firstname.dat): 

         ALAINA|ALANA
 ALAINE|ALANA
 ALANE|ALANA

        If no match is found, the default value is returned. If no default value is given, the original attribute value is returned.

        Example: replaceFromDictionnary("BOB","firstname.dat") ) returns "ROBERT"

        Parameters:
        attribute - attribute that should be normalized.
        dictionaryFileName - the name of the file where normalization data is described.
        defaultValue - default value if the attribute is not found.
        Returns:
        The resulting String. If no match is found, the input defaultValue is returned.

        public boolean filtermatch(java.lang.String attrValue)
        Help Support of conditional expressions (if then else) . The filter is an ldapfilter syntax It will be applied on the current entry. will return 'true' or 'false' Usage in computed attribute ?: filtermatch("(objectclass=inetorgperson)")?"hello folks":"hola thing" can have multiple if then else .... filtermatch("objectclass=inetorgperson")?"hello folks" :filtermatch("(|(objectclass=group)(objectclass=groupofuniquenames))" )?"group_"+cn:null
        Parameters:

        Returns:
        true if condition is met, false otherwise .
